articles.headline: U.S. Clears Google Acquisition of Travel Software
articles.snippet: The Justice Department has approved, with conditions, Google’s $700 million purchase of ITA.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department has approved, with conditions, Google’s $700 million purchase of ITA.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department on Friday approved Google’s $700 million acquisition of a flight search software maker, but imposed conditions limiting how Google could use the company’s technology, potentially opening the door to broader antitrust scrutiny of the search giant’s activities.

articles.headline: British Tabloid Accepts Blame in Cell Hacking
articles.snippet: News International, a division of Rupert Murdoch’s newspaper empire, offered to pay compensation after publicly apologizing to the people whose phones they illegally hacked.
articles.abstract: News International, a division of Rupert Murdoch’s newspaper empire, offered to pay compensation after publicly apologizing to the people whose phones they illegally hacked.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Faced with a cascade of lawsuits and a widening police investigation into illegal hacking of phone messages by the News of the World tabloid, its parent company on Friday publicly admitted wrongdoing, apologized and offered to pay damages to some of the people who are alleged to be victims of the paper.

articles.headline: Six Keys to Saving by Starting at Community College
articles.snippet: The most important things to think about if you’re trying to save money by starting at a community college.
articles.abstract: The most important things to think about if you’re trying to save money by starting at a community college.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Rich Johnston started college in the 1970s, four years at a standard university was out of the question financially. So he worked, knocked off two years of community college credits in 19 months and then worked some more.

articles.headline: In Portugal Crisis, Worries on Europe’s ‘Debt Trap’
articles.snippet: Portugal now follows Greece and Ireland to the European welfare office to get new loans on condition of ever more drastic spending cuts.
articles.abstract: Portugal now follows Greece and Ireland to the European welfare office to get new loans on condition of ever more drastic spending cuts.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — For the third time in a year the European Union is going through the same ritual, bailing out another insolvent country. Portugal now follows Greece and Ireland to the European welfare office to ask for new loans on the condition of ever more drastic spending cuts.

articles.headline: Japan Cargo Is Screened at U.S. Ports
articles.snippet: A system installed after the Sept. 11 attacks is now also being used to detect any radiation-tainted Japanese imports.
articles.abstract: A system installed after the Sept. 11 attacks is now also being used to detect any radiation-tainted Japanese imports.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Radiation detectors originally intended to thwart terrorists smuggling nuclear bombs into the country have been put to another use at this sprawling port across the bay from San Francisco.

articles.headline: Allies of Zimbabwe’s President Push for Quick Vote
articles.snippet: With no credible successor to unite the quarrelsome factions that threaten to splinter the country’s ruling party, Zimbabwe hurtles into another violent political season.
articles.abstract: With no credible successor to unite the quarrelsome factions that threaten to splinter the country’s ruling party, Zimbabwe hurtles into another violent political season.
articles.lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe — As Zimbabwe hurtles into another violent political season, President Robert Mugabe’s party is fiercely pushing for a quick election this year because of fears that the president’s health and vigor are rapidly ebbing, senior party officials said.

articles.headline: Late Clash on Abortion Shows Conservatives’ Sway
articles.snippet: The emergence of abortion as the most contentious issue holding up the budget deal highlighted the sway of social conservatives.
articles.abstract: The emergence of abortion as the most contentious issue holding up the budget deal highlighted the sway of social conservatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The emergence of abortion as the last and most contentious of the issues that held up the budget deal reached Friday night highlighted the enduring influence of social conservatives within the Republican Party even at a time when the Tea Party movement’s focus on fiscal austerity is getting most of the attention.

articles.headline: New York Subpoenas 2 Foreclosure-Related Firms
articles.snippet: The effort to clamp down on shoddy documentation provided to foreclose continued, with inquiries sent to the Steven J. Baum firm in upstate New York.
articles.abstract: The effort to clamp down on shoddy documentation provided to foreclose continued, with inquiries sent to the Steven J. Baum firm in upstate New York.
articles.lead_paragraph: Eric T. Schneiderman, the New York attorney general, has issued subpoenas to the state’s largest foreclosure law firm and a related company, indicating that his office has some doubts about the effort by state attorneys general to resolve questionable foreclosure practices among the nation’s top banks.

articles.headline: Enriching a Few at the Expense of Many
articles.snippet: Albert Meyer, a money manager, sees some international companies as models of pay practices that show more respect for shareholders than similar American companies do.
articles.abstract: Albert Meyer, a money manager, sees some international companies as models of pay practices that show more respect for shareholders than similar American companies do.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOME people say it doesn’t really matter how much companies pay their executives, at least as far as the shareholders are concerned. Whether investors prosper depends on the executives’ management skill, not on penny-ante items like pay, this argument goes.

articles.headline: It’s Time for Your Face-Lift, Miss Piggy
articles.snippet: Disney is aiming to rejuvenate the Muppets franchise with a new movie this fall.
articles.abstract: Disney is aiming to rejuvenate the Muppets franchise with a new movie this fall.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNIVERSAL CITY, Calif.
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: The Drought Is Over (at Least for C.E.O.’s)
articles.snippet: After shrinking during the recession, paychecks are growing again for top American executives.
articles.abstract: After shrinking during the recession, paychecks are growing again for top American executives.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAPPY days are back — in the corner office, at least.

articles.headline: Japanese Workers Braved Radiation for a Temp Job
articles.snippet: Before the quake, thousands of untrained laborers handled most of the dangerous work at nuclear plants.
articles.abstract: Before the quake, thousands of untrained laborers handled most of the dangerous work at nuclear plants.
articles.lead_paragraph: KAZO, Japan — The ground started to buck at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, and Masayuki Ishizawa could scarcely stay on his feet. Helmet in hand, he ran from a workers’ standby room outside the plant’s No. 3 reactor, near where he and a group of workers had been doing repair work. He saw a chimney and crane swaying like weeds. Everybody was shouting in a panic, he recalled.

articles.headline: Next on the Agenda for Washington: Fight Over Debt
articles.snippet: Republicans are expected to demand fundamental changes in policy on health care, the environment, abortion rights and more, as the price of their support for raising the debt ceiling.
articles.abstract: Republicans are expected to demand fundamental changes in policy on health care, the environment, abortion rights and more, as the price of their support for raising the debt ceiling.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The down-to-the-wire partisan struggle over cuts to this year’s federal budget has intensified concern in Washington, on Wall Street and among economists about the more consequential clash coming over increasing the government’s borrowing limit.

articles.headline: Concessions and Tension, Then a Deal
articles.snippet: Interviews with officials show how uncertain they were until virtually the last minute that they could prevent a shutdown.
articles.abstract: Interviews with officials show how uncertain they were until virtually the last minute that they could prevent a shutdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At one crucial moment in the game of chicken over a looming shutdown of the United States government, President Obama and the House speaker, John A. Boehner, faced off in the Oval Office. Mr. Boehner, a Republican heavily outnumbered in the room by Democrats, was demanding a provision to restrict financing to Planned Parenthood and other groups that provide abortions. Mr. Obama would not budge.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Spraying to Make Yards Green ... but With Paint, Not Water
articles.snippet: Arizona homeowners are exploring alternative approaches to maintaining green lawns, such as paint and artificial turf.
articles.abstract: Arizona homeowners are exploring alternative approaches to maintaining green lawns, such as paint and artificial turf.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — There used to be two kinds of homeowners in this scorching city, those with dazzling green lawns irrigated by sprinklers and those with more natural backyard expanses of rocks, cactuses and desert flora, which required no watering at all.

articles.headline: Newly Born, and Withdrawing From Painkillers
articles.snippet: Growing numbers of newborns across the country are struggling with addiction as prescription drug abuse ravages communities.
articles.abstract: Growing numbers of newborns across the country are struggling with addiction as prescription drug abuse ravages communities.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANGOR, Me. — The mother got the call in the middle of the night: her 3-day-old baby was going through opiate withdrawal in a hospital here and had to start taking methadone, a drug best known for treating heroin addiction, to ease his suffering.
articles.byline: By Abby Goodnough and Katie Zezima

articles.headline: Obama to Call for Broad Plan to Reduce Debt
articles.snippet: President Obama will call this week for Republicans to join him in writing a plan to raise revenue and reduce the growth of popular entitlement programs.
articles.abstract: President Obama will call this week for Republicans to join him in writing a plan to raise revenue and reduce the growth of popular entitlement programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will call this week for Republicans to join him in writing a broad plan to raise revenues and reduce the growth of popular entitlement programs, as the battle over the nation’s financial troubles moves past Friday’s short-term budget deal and into a wider and more consequential debate over the nation’s long-term fiscal health.

articles.headline: True to Mission, Comedy Central Still Strong at 20
articles.snippet: Twenty years on, Comedy Central is still the TV leader in comedy, its endurance the result of talent-spotting and demographic marketing.
articles.abstract: Twenty years on, Comedy Central is still the TV leader in comedy, its endurance the result of talent-spotting and demographic marketing.
articles.lead_paragraph: On television, the laughter is coming from every direction.

articles.headline: At Gannett, Furloughs but Nice Paydays for Brass
articles.snippet: There’s a dissonance between furloughs and layoffs for employees while chief executive compensation doubles.
articles.abstract: There’s a dissonance between furloughs and layoffs for employees while chief executive compensation doubles.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just in case Gannett employees thought 2011 might bring better news after years of layoffs and furloughs, the year was just four days old when a note landed in the in-box of people who work for the community news division saying, once again, they were required to take an unpaid week off.

articles.headline: Research In Motion Eyes a Rebound
articles.snippet: As R.I.M. prepares to introduce its first tablet computer, doubts about its future are great.
articles.abstract: As R.I.M. prepares to introduce its first tablet computer, doubts about its future are great.
articles.lead_paragraph: WATERLOO, Ontario — In a rare interview last week, Mike Lazaridis, one of Research In Motion’s two chief executives, was the one asking questions:

articles.headline: Qaddafi’s Handling of Media Shows Regime’s Flaws
articles.snippet: For journalists cloistered in Tripoli at the invitation of the government, its management, or rather staging, of public relations provided a singular view.
articles.abstract: For journalists cloistered in Tripoli at the invitation of the government, its management, or rather staging, of public relations provided a singular view.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — Even the Qaddafi government escort could not contain his disbelief at the sloppiness of the fraud: bloodstains his colleagues had left on bedsheets in a damaged hospital room for more than a week as evidence of civilian casualties from Western airstrikes.

articles.headline: New Doubts About Turning Plutonium Into a Fuel
articles.snippet: The nuclear crisis in Japan has intensified a conflict over a project to turn weapons-grade plutonium into a commercial fuel called mixed oxide, or mox.
articles.abstract: The nuclear crisis in Japan has intensified a conflict over a project to turn weapons-grade plutonium into a commercial fuel called mixed oxide, or mox.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a tract of government land along the Savannah River in South Carolina, an army of workers is building one of the nation’s most ambitious nuclear enterprises in decades: a plant that aims to safeguard at least 43 tons of weapons-grade plutonium by mixing it into fuel for commercial power reactors.
articles.byline: By Jo Becker and William J. Broad

articles.headline: Actors in Smaller Studios, Making Pictures for the Smaller Screen
articles.snippet: Instead of heading to television and movies, many young entertainers are now going to small production start-ups that specifically make video for the Web.
articles.abstract: Instead of heading to television and movies, many young entertainers are now going to small production start-ups that specifically make video for the Web.
articles.lead_paragraph: CULVER CITY, Calif. — The film set was professional, even if the actors kept messing up the scene by laughing at the star, who was flailing in front of a green screen, pretending to be eaten alive.

articles.headline: JPMorgan Accused of Breaking Its Duty to Clients
articles.snippet: A lawsuit sheds new light on one of Wall Street’s oldest problems — whether banks treat their clients’ money with the same care that they treat their own.
articles.abstract: A lawsuit sheds new light on one of Wall Street’s oldest problems — whether banks treat their clients’ money with the same care that they treat their own.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2007, as the first tremors of the coming financial crisis were being felt on Wall Street, top executives of JPMorgan Chase were raising red flags about a troubled investment vehicle called Sigma, which was based in London. But the bank chose not to move out $500 million in client assets that it had put into Sigma two months earlier.

articles.headline: Couric’s Rocky Five-Year Path to a Likely Parting With CBS
articles.snippet: As Katie Couric and the network negotiate how to end her five-year run as anchor of “CBS Evening News,” interviews show that her hiring was part of a larger experiment to lift the newscast’s ratings.
articles.abstract: As Katie Couric and the network negotiate how to end her five-year run as anchor of “CBS Evening News,” interviews show that her hiring was part of a larger experiment to lift the newscast’s ratings.
articles.lead_paragraph: For Katie Couric, the offer in 2006 to become the anchor of “CBS Evening News” came with another incentive, one she prized almost as highly, according to two of her friends: the chance to report for “60 Minutes,” the newsmagazine that for Ms. Couric stood for the kind of serious journalism she had always aspired to.

articles.headline: Close-Knit, New to the House, and Resistant to Blending In
articles.snippet: Even by the standards of Capitol Hill, where the bonds of friendship form quickly and endure, the four Republican freshmen from South Carolina stand out.
articles.abstract: Even by the standards of Capitol Hill, where the bonds of friendship form quickly and endure, the four Republican freshmen from South Carolina stand out.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even by the standards of Capitol Hill, where the bonds of friendship form quickly and endure, the four Republican freshmen from South Carolina stand out.

articles.headline: A New Push to Let H.I.V. Patients Accept Organs That Are Infected
articles.snippet: Organs from people infected with the virus that causes AIDS are suitable for transplant to patients who are already infected, doctors say.
articles.abstract: Organs from people infected with the virus that causes AIDS are suitable for transplant to patients who are already infected, doctors say.
articles.lead_paragraph: David Aldridge of Los Angeles had a kidney transplant in 2006, but he will soon need another. Like many people living with H.I.V., he suffers from kidney damage, either from the virus or from the life-saving medications that keep it at bay.

articles.headline: Leader’s Arrest in Ivory Coast Ends Standoff
articles.snippet: Laurent Gbagbo was taken after a weeklong siege of his residence and placed under the control of his rival, Alassane Ouattara.
articles.abstract: Laurent Gbagbo was taken after a weeklong siege of his residence and placed under the control of his rival, Alassane Ouattara.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by  Adam Nossiter,  Scott Sayare and  Dan Bilefsky.
articles.byline: By Adam Nossiter, Scott Sayare and Dan Bilefsky
